snippet: Violent encounters with guns occur, on average, more than twice an hour in the best sellers in PG-13 and R-rated movies, according to a study set for publication in Pediatrics.
abstract: Media Decoder blog; study, to be published in Pediatrics journal, confirms Hollywood's sharpest critics' suspicions that level of gun violence in top-selling PG-13 movies has been rising; research, conducted with support from Annenberg Public Policy Center and Robert Wood Johnson Foundation, finds violence levels exceed that in the most popular R-rated films.
lead_paragraph: Violent encounters with guns occur, on average, more than twice an hour in the best sellers in PG-13 and R-rated movies, according to a study set for publication in Pediatrics.

headline.main: Gun Violence in American Movies Is Rising, Study Finds
headline.print_headline: Gun Violence in American Movies Is Rising, Study Finds
